awd_titl_txt: WRF: Collaborative Research: Extended-range forecasts of atmospheric rivers for adaptive management of flood risk, water supply, and environmental flows in California
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will develop ways to improve the robustness of human and environmental water supplies in California and similar regions with highly variable climates. Adaptive control policies that explicitly account for uncertainty in forecasts of extreme storm events will be designed. This work will explicitly tailor water system operations for regional storm track patterns and associated forecast errors for those storm types. Expected outcomes include three major scientific advancements: 1) characterization and modeling of spatial and temporal uncertainty in extended-range forecasts of cold-season precipitation, temperature, and floods at different locations and lead times 2) this improved knowledge of forecast error structure will be coupled with computational approaches for water resources control policy design to develop adaptive policies that are robust to forecast uncertainty; 3) determination of how forecast-informed control policies should be designed for long-term climate uncertainty represented by decadal-scale droughts and floods. Through these outcomes, this work will support a shift toward integrating state-of-the-art climate information with decision-making in the water sector of California, and findings from this work will be transferable to other semi-arid regions with similar flood regimes.

This work will enable extensive interactions and technology transfer with key stakeholders in water management agencies in California throughout the project to promote the translation of research findings and methods into practice. All software and data analysis performed for this project will be open source and hosted on GitHub, enabling researchers around the world to reproduce and extend the project's findings. These software tools will be designed to support analyses on desktop computers as well as high-performance computing clusters, including NSF XSEDE resources, to support a range of decision-making processes. The team will advance graduate and undergraduate education in the key areas of data science and software design, identified in recent National Academy reports as critical issues for scientific reproducibility and workforce preparedness. These education expansions include of the PIs' statistics courses at Cornell and water resources engineering courses at UC Davis, incorporating simplified data analysis and modeling tasks from this project. Educational developments will be shared broadly through the ASCE Task Committee on Education (ECSTATIC).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The climate in California includes both extreme droughts and floods. The efficient management of surface reservoirs and groundwater aquifers is critical to buffer this variability. There is an opportunity to improve management by incorporating precipitation and streamflow forecasts into the operating rules that are used to control reservoir systems. This research developed modeling tools for reservoir simulation and optimization using forecast information, testing whether extended range (1-14 day) forecasts are sufficiently accurate to improve water supply security without increasing flood risk. To achieve this, we undertook three major projects, each with their own key outcomes.

First, we developed and tested reservoir control rules mapping observed and forecasted streamflow to one of several operational modes: flood control, conservation, and demand delivery. Experiments included a range of forecast lead times, where uncertainty at longer lead times was estimated using a statistical model of observed forecast errors. The control rules were evaluated based on their ability to balance water supply, flood risk, and environmental outcomes. The outcome of this project showed that control rules developed using this method are capable of improving multi-objective outcomes even with forecasts at short lead times (e.g., 3 days), and show the potential to integrate surface and groundwater management. This approach allows water managers to test how well operating rules would have performed during past extreme events, helping to build confidence in forecast-based operations.

Second, we investigated the potential to correct spatial errors in precipitation forecasts using statistical methods. This project aims to inform forecast-based reservoir management by identifying spatial patterns in forecasts that are often observed before heavy precipitation events in a region of interest. The outcome shows only slight improvement in the classification of heavy precipitation events overall, but would allow water managers to select a balance between misses and false alarms. The project also shows that the classification method is able to identify spatial patterns in forecasts that are consistent with heavy precipitation events along the West Coast of the U.S. Thus, the method can support risk-averse flood management, for example by informing reservoir releases when an event is forecasted over a larger spatial area outside the basin.

Third, we developed new statistical approaches to test reservoir operating rules under uncertain hydrologic scenarios. This includes time periods sampled from the historical record, as well as long-term model projections. This ensures that the operating rules that are optimized to use forecast information are also robust to hydrologic scenarios that are wetter or drier than anticipated. Outcomes show that these testing approaches can improve water supply, flood risk, and environmental objectives relative to operating rules that do not use forecast information. Software to perform these methods has been released open-source to support the testing of forecast-based operating rules.

Ultimately, the outcomes of this project support a transformative shift towards integrating state-of-the-art weather forecast information into water resources decision-making in California. This contribution is critically important given the growing stress that droughts and floods have placed on the state and the Western US more broadly over recent decades. Furthermore, the work under this project was conducted by graduate students who received extensive training in systems analysis and computational modeling, thus helping to train the next generation of water resources professionals.
